title: 112_hr2874
content: The Act may be cited as the "Abstinence Education Reallocation Act of 2011" and includes provisions for Sexual Risk Avoidance Education. The "Abstinence Education Reallocation Act of 2011" allows for grants to be awarded for qualified sexual risk avoidance education to youth and parents. The education must be age-appropriate, medically accurate, evidence-based, and focus on teaching the benefits of sexual abstinence as the optimal behavior for youth. The "Abstinence Education Reallocation Act of 2011" promotes teaching the benefits of refraining from nonmarital sexual activity, emphasizing self-regulation, goal setting, and the advantages of reserving sexual activity for marriage to prevent poverty and promote physical and emotional health. It also highlights the importance of healthy relationships and the societal benefits of bearing children within committed relationships. The curr_chunk emphasizes the skills needed to resist negative influences of the sex-saturated culture, understanding the impact of drugs, alcohol, and social media on sexual decision making, and prioritizing the health benefits of sexual abstinence. The curr_chunk focuses on awarding grants for sexual risk avoidance education programs targeting youth aged 12 to 19, prioritizing parent-child communication on healthy sexual decision making. It defines "age appropriate" and "evidence-based approach" for clarity. The curr_chunk defines terms like "medically accurate," "sexual abstinence," and "sexual activity" in the context of awarding grants for sexual risk avoidance education programs targeting youth aged 12 to 19. It emphasizes the importance of a clear theoretical base and practical implementation expertise relevant to the field. Authorization of Appropriations: $110,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2012-2016 from the Prevention and Public Health Fund for this Act. Up to $1,000,000 for Federal administrative costs, with 40% allocated for training and technical assistance by qualified experts. Qualified experts with experience in abstinence education, curriculum development, evaluation instruments, and training in sexual risk avoidance field.
